In the present study, we use the decomposition method to examine the impact of the mean duration on the other two factors: total number of patients per 1,000 people of the general population, and the mean number of visits per year in assessing its impact on the total number of hospitalization days.

In order to investigate the factors contributing to the changes in the average number of hospitalized days per person between 2000 and 2010 in Hong Kong, data on total population and public hospital admissions for this period (Table 1) were collected from the Census and Statistics Department and Hospital Authority, respectively. The Census statistics include both sexes and ages, while the episode-based hospitalization data contains information on age, gender, hospital, date of birth, district of residence, date of admission and discharge, disease code, duration of stay for each visit, and discharge destination.

Here we define the hospitalized days per person (HD) as the total number of hospitalized days in all public hospitals during the examining year (D) divided by the total population in the same year (P). The total number of hospitalization days is the most crucial factor in determining financial funding and planning of the public hospital system. The decomposition method described in this paper provides empirical evidence that the mean duration of stay plays a very significant role in determining the number of hospitalization days. Despite that, the frequency of visits per patient has increased from 1.98 to 2.14, and the hospital admission rate increased from 87.43 to 94.51 (possibly due to the ageing of the population). We still observed a 21% reduction in the number of hospitalized days per person, which contributes to the reduction of the mean duration of stay from 6.83 to 4.58 days. Hence, even a shorter average stay per hospital visit, which could induce 11 an increase in the number of re-visits, still leads to a reduction in the total number of hospitalization days.

With an ageing population, the number of people suffering from chronic illness has increased by more than 4% each year, which is larger than the increase in funding and the GDP growth of Hong Kong. [10] With one of the longest life expectancies in the world (81 years for males and 86 for females), people are living longer, but not necessarily healthier. [2, 11] Hence, we are dealing with an acute situation of ever-increasing demand for medical and health services.

Furthermore, due to improvements in medical services and patients' rights, more and more services have been demanded by the public and are being made available to patients, although some of the services require long waiting times (such as specialist out-patient clinics). A better management of the duration of stay in the hospital is an important element for controlling healthcare expenditures. Possible adverse patient satisfaction, arising from shorter stays, has not been included in the assessment; however, studies in the Netherlands suggest higher patient satisfaction scores for some specific items in hospital wards with shorter lengths of stay. [12] Additionally, the workload for the medical and health staff due to the shorter stays has not been properly measured and reflected in cost considerations. For example, arranging for surgery in the day, rather than admitting the patient overnight, implies that medical and health workers have less time to do the preparation and provide the necessary services for operation. These are important elements and are consistently neglected in assessing the "cost-effectiveness" of shorter stays in the hospital. 12 There are some limitations in applying the decomposition method as described in this study.

First, it is a non-parametric method and can be used only as an exploratory method. Second, we assume the workload on the medical and health workers per hospitalized day for any patient is the same, which is unlikely to be true. It is has been reported that the implementation of day surgery arrangements-as opposed to admitting the patient a day earlier-has indeed caused excessive workload for medical and healthcare workers.
